content: Following Protest, Coordinator Will Not Live at Senior House

tag: html body text table tbody tr td h1 span
content: Following Protest, Coordinator Will Not Live at Senior House

tag: html body text table tbody tr td b span
content: By Jennifer Krishnan

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p i span
content: ASSOCIATE NEWS EDITOR

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Residential coordinators will not live in Senior House next year, announced Dean for Student Life Larry G. Benedict at a meeting with concerned Senior House residents.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: “There will be none of these people living at Senior House next year,” Benedict said at the Friday afternoon meeting amidst cheers from the audience. The coordinator slated to be housed in Senior House will instead live at Eastgate.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Assistant Dean for Residential Programs Katherine G. O’Dair said that it was impossible to house a residential coordinator in Senior House because the the space for the coordinator had already been promised to a handicapped student.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Coordinators will also live in Next House and NW30, the new dormitory for graduate students which will open in Fall 2001.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Burton-Conner was also mentioned as a possible home for a residential coordinator. However, Burton-Conner president Kiwah K. Kendrick ’02 said that the dormitory was unlikely to accept the proposal in its current state. Benedict and O’Dair will meet with Burton-Conner tomorrow.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The Friday meeting was organized to deal with the negative student response to the residential coordinator proposal, which the deans announced earlier this month. About 75 students joined Benedict, O’Dair, Senior House Housemaster Henry Jenkins, and Director of Housing Operations Karen A. Nilsson for the discussion.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p font b span
content: DSL will rewrite job description

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Benedict and O’Dair also agreed to rewrite the job description for residential coordinators. “The language [in the original proposal] was atrocious,” Benedict said.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: O’Dair added that coordinators would not be granted any disciplinary or judicial power.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Under the new proposal, residential coordinators will serve both graduate students and undergraduates, O’Dair said.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The original plan included one coordinator for all graduate students and three for the undergraduates.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p font b span
content: Deans address communication

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: After announcing the new residential coordinator plans, Benedict and O’Dair addressed student complaints about ineffective communication between students and the administration.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Dormitory Council President Jeffrey C. Roberts ’02 said he had known about the proposal as early as December. Dormcon didn’t inform the public of the status of the proposal because it felt it did not have enough details to advertise, said Dormcon Vice President Matthew S. Cain ’02. “It was basically a big miscommunication,” Cain said.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Roberts added that when he was first informed, the proposal “was not a plan ... my expectation was that when it became a plan, [the dormitories involved] would be be the first to hear. We just had a breakdown in communication.”

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The administration had also communicated with the Undergraduate Association and the Graduate Student Council, O’Dair said.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: “One thing we’ve learned is that we need to use multiple communication mechanisms, because as it is, the word doesn’t get out,” O’Dair said.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p font b span
content: Students prefer new proposal

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Most attendees at Friday’s meeting acknowledged that Benedict’s new proposal was an improvement.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Robin H. Ivester ’01, who wrote the summary of student concerns provided to Benedict on Friday, said that Benedict’s appearance at the meeting helped rebuild students’ trust in the administration.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: “I think what he did shows us very clearly that he’s willing to work with us, for us,” she said.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Other students commended the administration for responding to their concerns.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: “I was pretty pleased with the outcome of the meeting,” said Senior House resident M. Maitland Lederer ’03. “I was glad to see communication [between students and administrators] and not just yelling and name-calling.”

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Lederer added that residential coordinators were “not a bad idea in principle” and that her main objections to the initial proposal were the original implementation plans and the wording.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: “It’s clear that Dean Benedict cares about the well-being of the students,” said Senior House resident Geoffrey L. Goodell ’01.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: However, Goodell expressed reservations about the administration’s failure to provide students with a long-term plan. He added that, without seeing Benedict’s long-term vision, the residential coordinator plan seems “like a solution begging for a problem.”

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Meanwhile, the GSC expressed its support for the new proposal.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: “Among grad students, we like the concept of having another person to help with residential life,” said GSC Housing and Community Affairs Chair Shunmugavelu D. Sokka. “Undergraduates have a lot of support already, but we favor any help we can get.”

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p font b span
content: Students draft bill of rights

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The controversy surrounding this proposal has inspired a group of students, led by Lederer, to create a “Students’ Bill of Rights.” Currently in its early stages, the document outlines students’ basic housing rights.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Lederer said the idea had been tossed around by the UA and other groups. “It’s not incredibly novel, but it’s something that hasn’t been done yet,” she said.
